botanical_details.genus: Rosa can be deciduous or semi-evergreen shrubs or scrambling climbers, with usually thorny stems bearing compound pinnate leaves and solitary or clustered flowers. Flowers may be followed by showy red or purple fruits in some varieties.
botanical_details.horticultural_group: Rambler roses are vigorous shrubs with long, arching, thorny or smooth stems carrying glossy foliage and large sprays of small, single or double, often fragrant flowers in early summer

how_to_grow.cultivation: Grow in full sun in moderately fertile, humus-rich, moist but well-drained soil, on a large arch, pergola, wall or fence, or into a tree; for more advice, see rose cultivation
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by hardwood cuttings in autumn, by softwood cuttings under glass in spring and summer, or by T-budding in summer
how_to_grow.pests: May be affected by brown scale, rose aphids, rose leafhopper, rose leaf-rolling sawfly, large rose sawfly, rose slug sawfly or slugworm, scurfy rose scale, glasshouse red spider mite, caterpillars, rabbits and deer; leaf-cutting bees may use rose leaves to make nests for their larvae
how_to_grow.diseases: May be affected by rose black spot, rose rust and rose powdery mildew, canker, crown gall, honey fungus, downy mildews, and virus diseases, and by replant disease and rose dieback
